headline: Bacon-Wrapped Cherries
description: Broiled cherries wrapped in bacon are quick and easy enough to impress unexpected guests and tasty enough that they might not leave â€” make make extra!
name: Bacon-Wrapped Cherries
recipeIngredient: 36 maraschino cherries, stemmed, drained and juice reserved

recipeInstructions.text: Set the oven rack about 6 inches from the heat source and preheat the oven's broiler.
Wrap each cherry with a bacon half, secure with a toothpick, and arrange on a baking sheet. Drizzle reserved cherry juice over wrapped cherries.
Broil in the preheated oven until bacon is crisped to your liking, 3 to 10 minutes.

review.reviewBody: A mother of a friend uses small pieces of spaghetti instead of toothpicks. Makes for an edible toothpick! I've made them a few times since. 5 stars

Made these to pair with some Maple Bacon Moonshine Old Fashions. Everyone enjoyed this unique pairing. Before wrapping the cherries in the bacon and sticking them on the skewer, I smoked the cherries for an hour on my Traeger @180 degrees. Then wrapped in bacon, placed on the skewer. I upped the heat to 400 and threw the skewers back on. After 10 minutes, I turned them over and let them go another 10. I was using thick cut bacon, so I increased the heat to 450 for an additional 10 minutes before pulling them off the grill. Let them cool, and garnished our signature cocktails. They were a hit!
Two thumbs up from everyone who had them. I drizzled juice on before putting in oven,divine

Overall, i was very surprised with the flavor of this. It actually tasted pretty good. I could see this being served at a wine/cheese type party or just a party with finger foods, as it tasted great at room temp. My oven has broil temperatures so i broiled mine at 475. I checked after 7 minutes and noticed the tops were crisp but the bottoms were soggy so i flipped them and cooked for 7 more minutes(14 min total). I also didn't use toothpicks, the bacon stayed wrapped just fine, and found i only needed 1/3 of a strip of bacon per cherry..and could probably cut that back to 1/4 if you were making these to feed a crowd :)
